Headline: Crafting Asymmetric Solutions, A Business Problem at a Time| Building Businesses| Scaling Brands| LinkedIn Top Voice| Teacher and Student of Behavior| Ex Unilever, Royal Enfield, Pernod Ricard| ICF Certified Coach
Comment:
Rishabh Mariwala - Very well said. Proposition is a promise, product is the proof of that promise. If both don't work in tandem, there is no way to achieve success. The problem is that in today's environment, the complete marketing mix is something that many don't understand and many among those don't want to understand.

Interestingly, there is another argument to this that Byron Sharp presents where he says that the model to success lies in a perpetual cycle of new recruits. It is based on the assumption that in today's world of hypercharged choice, stickiness is difficult to achieve let alone loyalty. While that might be the argument, it still doesn't take away from the first line i wrote.

Headline: ðŸš€ Head of Revenue - USA @ Kerala Ayurveda | Ex-Founder (RecruVia AI) | Scaling a $75 Mn Market Cap + 85 year Old Legacy Brand $$ 100x | All Things Growth | Lawyer |
Comment:
Weâ€™ve maintained 30-40%+ retention, and even when revenue dipped by almost 50% for 3 months after pausing ads to optimize our supply chain, ops and generally taper costs, we stayed afloatâ€”thanks to loyal customers. I know so many brands that would shut down if ads were paused for more than a month. In fact, 10% of our revenue comes from retention campaigns, beyond regular orders.

Quality, customer experience, and brand values are key. A strong social media presence may get your foot in the door, but itâ€™s the experience that keeps customers coming back. Many brands overthink discounts for existing customers while focusing purely on new customer acquisition. However, the LTV of existing customers is far better if basics are sorted, and upto 30% discounts to keep them happy are a small dip in margins (but still profitable) when you're not blindly spending on CAC.

Building a customer base is crucial, but at a certain point, once you have a decent number, focus on quality, customer experience and horizontal expansionâ€”adding more SKUs to cater to the needs and lifestyle of your existing customersâ€”becomes key to survival in the long run. 

Being bootstrapped has helped keep blinders on when it comes to sticking to sustainable growth.
processed_comment: weve maintained retention and even when revenue dipped by almost for months after pausing ads to optimize our supply chain ops and generally taper costs we stayed afloatthanks to loyal customers i know so many brands that would shut down if ads were paused for more than a month in fact of our revenue comes from retention campaigns beyond regular orders quality customer experience and brand values are key a strong social media presence may get your foot in the door but its the experience that keeps customers coming back many brands overthink discounts for existing customers while focusing purely on new customer acquisition however the ltv of existing customers is far better if basics are sorted and upto discounts to keep them happy are a small dip in margins but still profitable when youre not blindly spending on cac building a customer base is crucial but at a certain point once you have a decent number focus on quality customer experience and horizontal expansionadding more skus to cater to the needs and lifestyle of your existing customersbecomes key to survival in the long run being bootstrapped has helped keep blinders on when it comes to sticking to sustainable growth

Headline: Profit â€‹> Growth | Designing Systems for Clarity in eCommerce
Comment:
LTV and retention kicks in usually after ~30-45 days from 1st purchase. 

Early stage business usually do not have the runway to sustain built over LTV. 

Product RnD means more customers. 

More Customers means more marketing spends. 

More marketing spends mean more investment.

And if it is not coming from 1st purchase profitability, then it is coming from lending>>> Increasing your to debt to income proportion. 

Agreed that the brands that win are the ones that are remembered for their experiences, but only if they manage to sustain past ~3 years mark.

Headline: Founder of AATHIYAM, NEWTOS & PreBuy | FMCG & Direct-to-Retail Expert | Scaling B2B Brands | Food Brand Acquisition & Market Expansion | 20+ Years in Distribution & Growth Strategy
Comment:
Rishabh Mariwala 
Product-Market Fit Matters More Than You Think  

Your story, brand packaging, marketing, and branding strategy can drive your first saleâ€”but after that, only the product truly matters.  

While discussing with many founders through PreBuyâ€”Indiaâ€™s first tech and data-driven Direct-to-Retail company, helping D2C brands launch, scale, and sustain their B2B growth, I noticed a common challenge:  

Many brands fail to fully validate their products. They rely on limited sampling within their own circle, without real market data or insights. This leads to a critical gap in product consistency and repeat sales.  

Brands often place their products across D2C, B2B, marketplaces, and quick commerce, thinking turnover is growing. However, the real test comes after 3-12 months when repeat purchase data reveals true demand. Many donâ€™t track this properly, mistaking new customers and new retail shelves as continuous growth.  

Without repeat purchases, the numbers start catching up and after a year, brands struggle to sustain growth  

This is exactly the problem we solve at PreBuyâ€”a data and tech-enabled Direct-to-Retail company that ensures brands make informed decisions based on real market insights.  
PREBUY builds brands

Headline: Cluster Head - TVS Srichakra Limited | Castrol | Marico | Hul | IIMK |
Comment:
This nails a fundamental truth about consumer brandsâ€”marketing gets attention, but product earns loyalty.

Many brands focus heavily on customer acquisition, but without retention, itâ€™s just a leaky bucket. Repeat purchases and word-of-mouth come from a great product and experience, not just clever marketing.

Metrics like retention, frequency, and NPS truly indicate if a business is sustainable. In a world where customers have endless choices, being memorable beyond the first purchase is what separates brands from trends.

Well said! Would love to hear examples of brands that have successfully built loyalty beyond their initial hype.
